definition:
Let $\vec{a}$ and $\vec{b}$ be two vectors in the plane (or in a vector
space). The [*difference vector*]{} or [*difference*]{}
$\vec{a}\!-\!\vec{b}$ of $\vec{a}$ and $\vec{b}$ is a vector $\vec{d}$
such that $$\vec{b}+\vec{d} = \vec{a}.$$ Thus we have $$\begin{aligned}
\vec{b}+(\vec{a}\!-\!\vec{b}) = \vec{a}.\end{aligned}$$

According to the procedure of forming the sum of vectors by setting the
addends one after the other, the equation (1) tallies with the picture
below; when the minuend and the subtrahend emanate from a common initial
point, their difference vector can be directed from the terminal point
of the subtrahend to the terminal point of the minuend.

(-2,-1)(4,2.5) (0,0) (0,0)(-1.5,2) (-1.5,2)(4,1) (0,0)(4,1)
(2.1,0.2)[$\vec{a}$]{} (-1,0.7)[$\vec{b}$]{}
(1.6,1.76)[$\vec{a}\!-\!\vec{b}$]{} (-2,-1)[.]{} (4,2.5)[.]{}

**Remark.** It is easily seen that the difference $\vec{a}\!-\!\vec{b}$
is same as the sum vector $$\vec{a}\!+\!(-\vec{b})$$ where $-\vec{b}$ is
the [*opposite vector*]{} of $\vec{b}$: it may be represented by the
directed line segment from the terminal point of $\vec{b}$ to the
initial point of $\vec{b}$.
